 I have to admit, I'm pretty flabergasted everytime I read someone make this claim. The Bible definitely forbids sex between people of the same sex--even many people who condone same-sex relationships admit the Bible says what it says. 
 
 It would be better to simply admit disagreement with the Bible and live with that rather than trying to make it not say something that it clearly does.
 
 
Couple this with the fact that there are many gay people who do not choose to be gay, and the view common the all Christians that God is responsible for how we enter the world, and the evidence provided by the Bible that the Christian God is love,
 
 . . . If you claim that God would make people who are solely attracted to people of the same gender, and yet call that attraction a sin (remember Jesus' words about looking on people in lust and committing adultery in ones heart), then you must consider that this does not seem to be the action of a God of love.

 
 That's not a recipe for God having mandated same-sex relationships. It's simply a realization that bad things exist in the world that God could keep from happening if He wanted . . . birth defects, genetic disposition toward alcohol, etc., etc., etc. If your logic held true and God would never allow anything unpleasant on people then many things in the world that happen to exist simply would not. There is no more reason to think that God could never allow people to be attracted to people of the same gender in a world that knows it's wrong than, say He would allow a person to grow up in an abusive home and turn to a life of crime. The point being of course, that no one ever said God was obligated to make us in a way that guarantees a trouble-free life.

 We're making progress, albeit at a snail's pace. But the progression is obvious and unmistakable. For example, we no longer burn witches at the stake or justify slavery using the Bible. We no longer view certain diseases as resulting from demonic possession nor do we consider homosexuality as a perversion deserving of medical treatment. We don't consider women to be subservient to men (a biblical concept) or that disobedient children should be stoned to death (another biblical concept). 
 
 I believe with certainty that, within a few years, same-sex unions will become legitimized within American society. It's inevitable and it's already happening. And to whatever extent certain churches choose to adopt or not adopt such a policy is, to me, irrelevant. I suspect that, some day, our children will wonder why previous generations discriminated against gays to the same extent that today's children wonder why previous generations discriminated against blacks. This, too, is already happening. The key, I think, is education and awareness - 40 years ago, a sleepy and complacent America was forced to confront the reality of racial discrimination and then gender discrimination. In each such case, rear-guard, reactionary forces attempted to maintain the status quo. They failed. And with regard to gay civil rights, they will fail again.

But not a fundamental one. If we accept that the laws are against all homosexuality, which has been called into question by Jo, the position is:
 
 In 2006 BCE the wages of sin were death: homosexuals deserved to die
 
 In 2006 CE the wages of sin are death: homosexuals deserve to die
 
 Happily, that penalty has been taken on in the latter case by the death of Jesus Christ. Saying that this is a change is like saying someone no longer demanding money off you when it has been payed back on your account is changing their position. God sets the rules, which have stayed the same. How these rules effect us has been changed, but that follows from the nature of the rules.

 We're under a New Covenant. In other words, the New Testament. Just because God made a better promise to us now than before doesn't mean He changed. 
 Actually, Paul scolds the Galatians for observing the Law. He says in Galatians 3:2, "I would like to learn just one thing from you: Did you receive the Spirit by observing the Law, or by believing what you heard?" 
 
 Christ redeemed us from the Law. Galatians 3:13, "Christ redeemed us from the curse of the Law by becoming a curse for us, for it is written, 'Cursed is everyone who is hung on a tree.' He redeemed us in order that the blessing given to Abraham might come to the Gentiles through Christ Jesus, so that by faith we might receive the promise of the Spirit."
 
 So what was the purpose of the Law in the first place? Galatians 3:19 says, "What, then, was the purpose of the law? It was added because of transgressions until the Seed to whom the promise referred had come. The law was put into effect through angels by a mediator."
 
 In other words, because people in the early days of the Old Testament were sinning so much, God put the Law down so they wouldn't sin. This was temporary until Christ came.  Galatians 3:23 & 24 says, "Before this faith came, we were held prisoners by the Law, locked up until faith should be revealed. So the Law was put in charge to lead us to Christ that we might be justified by faith."
Easyrider

Purposes of the Law
 
 From my review of scripture there are four major purposes of the law. The first is that the law was intended to show us the character and morality of the sovereign God. If we want to know what God's opinion is concerning adultery or murder, we can look at the sixth and seventh commandments to realize that God does not approve of them. If we want to know if we are involved in idol worship (such as money), we can look at God's second commandment, as well as Matthew 6:24, and Luke 16:13, to see what God's word says about that. But the most important realization that we can come to is that there is but one righteous and sovereign God who is clearly defined through His divine law, and that divine law is perfect.
 
 "For the law of the Lord is perfect, reviving the soul." 
 (Psalm 19:7)
 
 
 The second major purpose of the law is that it is a tutor, or a teacher, to lead us to Christ. 
 
 "So the law was put in charge to lead us to Christ, that we might
 be justified by faith." (Galatians 3:24)
 
 "Indeed I would not have know what sin was except through the
 law."  (Romans 7:7)
 
 In Galatians 3:19 the apostle Paul wrote, "What, then was the purpose of the law? It was added because of transgression until the Seed to whom the promise referred (Christ) had come." The main point here is that man needs to have some set of guidelines, or law, as a reference to know whether or not he is sinful. Without the law, man indeed did not know what sin was, but once the law was given, three things happened: (1) Man knew the moral character of the righteous God; (2) Man knew by his review of the law that he was sinful;
 
 "For all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God."
 (Romans 3:23)
 
 (3) Man came to the realization that an unfathomable gulf exists between the righteous God and unrighteous, sinful man, and therefore a savior was needed to bridge the gap. 
 "What a wretched man I am! Who will rescue me from this
 body of death? Thanks be to God - through Jesus Christ our
 Lord." (Romans 7:24-25)
 
 
 "But now a righteousness from God, apart from the law, has
 been made known....This righteousness from God comes 
 through faith in Jesus Christ..." (Romans 3:21, 22)
 
 The third purpose of the law is that it is a guide for Christians to live by. Whereas the law was initially provided as a tutor to lead us to Christ, the law also serves as a reminder to keep us "in" Christ. One of the interesting things that happens to a Christian in his "walk" is that the closer he gets to God, the more aware he is of his sinful nature. This realization serves the purpose of keeping us close to Christ, depending on and trusting in Him for our salvation. 
 
 So the law is meant to guide us in our day-to-day walk of faith in Christ. Now there is one extremely important observation that needs to be addressed here. That has to do with the relationship of the law to salvation. Keeping the law does not result in eternal life or salvation. That was never the purpose of the law in regards to man. But it was the purpose of Christ to fulfill that law on our behalf, so that by faith in Him we could all become righteous in the eyes of God. 
 
 "Do not think that I have come to abolish the Law or the
 Prophets; I have not come to abolish them but to fulfill
 them." (Jesus, Matthew 5:17)
 
 "(In Christ)....We have been released from the law so that
 we serve in the new way of the Spirit." (Romans 7:6)
 
 This is one of the biggest stumbling blocks that Christians and even non-Christians get caught up in - trying to "keep" the law, or trying to do something to help win their salvation.
 
 "Know that a man is not justified (righteous) by observing
 the law, but by faith in Jesus Christ....(by) observing the 
 law no one will be justified." (Galatians 2:16)
 
 It would do us well to forget about the law as far as our salvation goes, and try to remember it as a guide for daily Christian living. 
 
 The last purpose of the law is to show us where there may be "traps" and pitfalls in our lives. For instance, by not committing adultery, we don't have to worry about getting shot at by a jealous husband, or a jealous wife. Our reputations and our consciences stay clear from disgrace. Our marriages remain stronger, and our families tend to stay together longer. Furthermore, we are free from any discipline from God that might take place should we commit such a sin, and we tend to stay out of the "clutches" of Satan at the same time.
 
 "...Hand this man over to Satan, so that the sinful nature
 may be destroyed and his spirit saved on the day of the
 Lord." (1 Corinthians 5:5)
 
 Another example is if we keep God's law about not stealing, we don't have to worry about going to jail. And so it goes from law to law. The law is there for our protection, and grants us liberty from many adverse and unpleasant consequences. 
 
 In summary, the law serves four major purposes:
 
 1. It shows us the moral character of God.
 2. It defines what sin is and serves as a tutor to lead us to Christ.
 3. It is a guide for Christian living
 4. It can keep us from suffering the adverse consequences of various sins.
Matthew S

Purposes of the Law
 
 In summary, the law serves four major purposes:
 
 1. It shows us the moral character of God.
 2. It defines what sin is and serves as a tutor to lead us to Christ.
 3. It is a guide for Christian living
 4. It can keep us from suffering the adverse consequences of various sins.
